text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two horizontal registers each containing a full-width scene; the upper and lower scenes are separated by a thin ruled line. Latin text appears in a single column above the top scene and below the bottom scene, framed by simple ruled borders. The images occupy the central space, with wide blank margins at left and right and framing lines delineating each scene.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textualis with frequent abbreviations and clear angular letterforms

color_scheme.color_usage: Flat washes of yellow, green, and red delineate robes and architectural elements; red ochre is reserved for depiction of blood in the martyrdom scenes; brown ink outlines define contours and drapery folds. The palette is economical and structured, with green garments for the condemned, yellow for the presiding judge, and orange-tinged tunics for the executioner. Original colors are well preserved, with minimal darkening or pigment loss.

features: Two-part vertical sequence in separate registers
Left-aligned seated judge figure counterbalanced by right-side execution scene
Central standing executioner linking both registers
Bodies of martyrs overlap to suggest forward motion
Architectural niche in lower register mirrors empty background above

decorative_elements: Simple ruled rectangular borders around each scene

drawing_technique.line_style: Evenly weighted brown-ink outlines executed with a quill, defining figures and drapery contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal; flat color application without hatch or tonal gradation except for blood detail
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No linear perspective; figures are arranged parallel to the picture plane with hierarchical scaling of importance

scene_relationships.subject: Beheading of two martyrs before a seated judge
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Continues the martyrdom narrative by showing the condemned taken to an architectural setting
visual_connections: The seated judge in yellow appears in both registers
The central executioner holds a sword in both scenes
Martyrs wear green robes in both registers

scene_relationships.subject: Martyrs executed within an architectural niche
visual_connections: Judge and executioner maintain identical postures and dress
Green-robed martyrs reappear now within a stone niche
Blood depicted in red ochre flows similarly in both scenes

visual_continuity: Flat color washes using the same palette
Seated judge figure repeats in left position
Standing executioner central in each register
Martyrs’ green robes across both scenes
Red blood accents in each scene

content_theme.scene_description: Upper register: Four figures occupy a shallow stage. On the left a crowned judge sits on a simple bench, wearing a full-length yellow robe with angular folds; his hands rest on the hem of his cloak. To his right stands a youthful executioner in an orange-tinted tunic, bare-legged and barefoot, holding a large straight sword vertically. Two martyrs in long green tunics lean forward from right to left, their necks already cut, blood rendered in vivid red ochre. One decapitated head lies at their feet, a second head floats just above, separated from the bodies. The spatial arrangement is flat, figures aligned against a blank background. Costume details include the judge’s crown with three fleurons, the executioner’s curly hair rendered in brown ink, and the martyrs’ simple belted gowns. Gestural interaction is minimal: the judge observes, the executioner stands ready, the martyrs slump forward in death.

religious: Martyrs in green robes without nimbuses
secular: Seated judge in crown and yellow robe
Executioner in orange tunic with bare feet

architectural: Stone-faced architectural niche in lower register

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth surface with visible pricking and faint ruling lines for text layout
technical_features.preservation_condition: Good overall; pigments are vivid with minimal flaking, slight cockling at corners, red ochre shows minor abrasion
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in brown ink beneath figure outlines
Faint ruling pattern evident across parchment
Layered pigment application with occasional raised gesso under green areas

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-register martyrdom scene likely originates from a mid-13th-century monastic scriptorium in northern France, reflecting the period’s restrained palette and economical use of pigment. The Gothic textualis and disciplined layout suggest a workshop accustomed to producing liturgical martyrologies for clerical audiences. The consistent iconography—yellow-clad judge, green-robed martyrs, and the central executioner—demonstrates a visual formula designed for immediate recognition by ecclesiastical users. While the compositions lack developed spatial depth, they convey narrative clarity through repeated motifs and linear progression from trial to execution. The absence of gilding or luxurious borders indicates a practical manuscript intended more for daily reference than for ostentatious display. Nonetheless, the confident underdrawing, careful ruling, and layered pigments speak to technical proficiency and the influence of the Parisian illumination tradition. Iconographically, the martyrs’ bare feet and flowing blood emphasize their human sacrifice, while the calm, detached judge figure may allude to divine judgment. Comparative analysis with contemporaneous martyrologies shows similar framing devices but this manuscript’s plain, methodical presentation suggests a transitional moment between Romanesque boldness and High Gothic refinement, merging traditional narrative clarity with emerging stylistic restraint.
